title: 103_s1127
content:
Title XI of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new part called "Rural Community Service" with the purpose of providing findings and establishing a program for rural community service. The Congress finds that rural centers are facing pressing problems in various areas, and there are people in rural institutions with underutilized skills that can help address these issues. The purpose of this part is to provide incentives to rural academic institutions to enable them to contribute towards solving rural problems. Incentives provided to rural academic institutions to collaborate with private and civic organizations in solving pressing community problems. The Secretary is authorized to carry out a program providing assistance to eligible institutions for authorized activities. Applications for rural community service grants are outlined in section 1173. Each eligible institution seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary, describing the activities and services needed. The application must include assurances that the institution will form a consortium with entities such as a community college, local educational agency, local government, business, or nonprofit institution to implement the program. The Secretary has the authority to waive the consortium requirement. The Secretary may waive consortium requirements for applicants with an integrated plan. Priority is given to joint projects with other programs. Selection procedures will be established by the Secretary through regulation. "Authorized activities under SEC. 1174 include waivers for consortium requirements, priority for joint projects, and selection procedures set by the Secretary." Grant funds under this part are used for planning, research, training, and services to assist rural communities with workforce preparation, poverty alleviation, healthcare, education, elderly and disability issues, family and children problems, crime prevention, housing, infrastructure, economic development, farming, and environmental concerns. Grant funds under this part are used for planning, research, training, and services to assist rural communities with workforce preparation, poverty alleviation, healthcare, education, elderly and disability issues, family and children problems, crime prevention, housing, infrastructure, economic development, farming, environmental concerns, and addressing accessibility barriers for individuals with disabilities and economically disadvantaged individuals. The Secretary will appoint a peer review panel to evaluate applications for funding under this part. The panel will be geographically diverse and include experts from various sectors. Funds will be disbursed according to the panel's recommendations. ``SEC. 1176. DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS.

Grants under this part may be awarded on a multiyear basis, with a maximum of 5 years per institution. The Secretary will ensure equitable geographic distribution of grants and require a matching contribution from applicants and local governments.

``SEC. 1177. DESIGNATION OF RURAL GRANT INSTITUTIONS. The Secretary will designate eligible institutions as 'Rural Grant Institutions' to establish a national network for sharing project results across the nation. The term 'rural area' refers to areas outside urbanized areas with populations of 75,000 or more. An 'eligible institution' is a higher education institution located in a rural area that serves students from rural or contiguous areas and promotes postsecondary educational opportunities for residents in those areas. The eligible institution in rural areas must have the capacity to provide resources responsive to the needs of the community, offer professional programs, and demonstrate a sense of responsibility to the rural area and its people. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out the provisions of this part each fiscal year. If the amount appropriated is less than 50 percent of the funds for part A, the Secretary will make up the difference from funds allocated for part A.
